questions.question: Which statement with respect to the step climb is correct?

options.content: A step climb provides better economy than a cruise climb
Performing a step climb based on economy can be limited by the 1.3g altitude
In principle a step climb is performed immediately after the aircraft has exceeded the optimum altitude
A step climb may not be performed unless it is indicated in the filed flight plan

questions.question: Which statement with respect to the step climb is correct?

options.content: A step climb is executed because ATC desires a higher altitude
A step climb is executed in principle when, just after levelling off, the 1.3g altitude is reached
Executing a desired step climb at high altitude can be limited by buffet onset at g-loads larger than 1
A step climb must be executed immediately after the aeroplane has exceeded the optimum altitude

questions.question: The lift coefficient decreases during a glide at a constant Mach number, mainly because the:

options.content: TAS decreases
glide angle increases
IAS increases
aircraft mass decreases

questions.question: An aeroplane carries out a descent from FL410 to FL270 at cruise Mach number, and from FL270 to FL100 at the IAS reached at FL270. How does the angle of descent change in the first and in the second part of the descent? Assume idle thrust and clean configuration and ignore compressibility effects.

options.content: Increases in the first part; is constant in the second
Increases in the first part; decreases in the second
Is constant in the first part; decreases in the second
Decreases in the first part; increases in the second

questions.question: During a glide at constant Mach number the pitch angle of the aeroplane will:

options.content: decrease
increase
increase at first and decrease later on
remain const

questions.question: If a flight is performed with a higher “Cost Index” at a given mass, which of the following will occur?

options.content: A better long range
A higher cruise Mach number
A lower cruise Mach number
A better maximum range

questions.question: During a descent at constant Mach Number, the margin to low speed buffet will:

options.content: decrease, because the lift coefficient decreases
increase, because the lift coefficient decreases
remain constant, because the Mach number remains constant
increase, because the lift coefficient increases

questions.question: A jet aeroplane is climbing with constant IAS. Which operational speed limit is most likely to be reached?

options.content: The stalling speed
The minimum control speed air
The Mach limit for the Mach trim system
The maximum operating Mach number

questions.question: ETOPS flight is a twin-engine jet aeroplane flight conducted over a route where no suitable airport is within an area of:

options.content: 75 minutes flying time at the approved one engine out cruise speed
60 minutes flying time in still air at the approved one engine out cruise speed
60 minutes flying time in still air at the normal cruising speed
30 minutes flying time at the normal cruising speed

questions.question: The danger associated with low speed and/or high speed buffet:

options.content: limits the manoeuvring load factor at high altitudes
can be reduced by increasing the load factor
exists only above M<sub>MO</sub>
has to be considered at take-off and landing

questions.question: Which data can be extracted from the buffet onset boundary chart?

options.content: The value of the Mach number at which low speed and shock stall occur at various weights and altitudes
The values of the Mach number at which low speed buffet and Mach buffet occur at various masses and altitudes
The value of maximum operating Mach number (M<sub>MO</sub>) at various masses and power settings
The value of the critical Mach number at various masses and altitudes

questions.question: Which of the following factors determines the maximum flight altitude in the “buffet onset boundary” graph?

options.content: Aerodynamics
Theoretical ceiling
Service ceiling
Economy

questions.question: The optimum cruise altitude increases:

options.content: if the aeroplane mass is decreased
if the temperature (OAT) is increased
if the tailwind component is decreased
if the aeroplane mass is increased

questions.question: Which of the following statements with regard to the optimum cruise altitude (best fuel mileage or range) is correct?

options.content: An aeroplane usually flies above the optimum cruise altitude, as this provides the largest specific range
An aeroplane sometimes flies above or below the optimum cruise altitude, because ATC normally does not allow aeroplanes to fly continuously at the optimum cruise altitude
An aeroplane always flies below the optimum cruise altitude, as otherwise Mach buffet can occur
An aeroplane always flies on the optimum cruise altitude, because this is most attractive from an economy point of view

questions.question: The optimum altitude:

options.content: is the altitude up to which cabin pressure of 8000 ft can be maintained
increases as mass decreases and is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its maximum
decreases as mass decreases
is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its minimum

questions.question: Under which condition should you fly considerably lower (4000 ft or more) than the optimum altitude?

options.content: If, at the lower altitude, either more headwind or less tailwind can be expected
If, at the lower altitude, either considerably less headwind or considerably more tailwind can be expected
If the maximum altitude is below the optimum altitude
If the temperature is lower at the low altitude (high altitude inversion)

questions.question: What happens to the specific range with one or two engines inoperative?

options.content: At first improved and later reduced
It decreases
It increases
Unaffected by engine failure

questions.question: The optimum cruise altitude is:

options.content: the pressure altitude up to which a cabin altitude of 8000 ft can be maintained
the pressure altitude at which the speed for high speed buffet as TAS is a maximum
the pressure altitude at which the highest specific range can be achieved
the pressure altitude at which the fuel flow is a maximum

questions.question: The maximum operating altitude for a certain aeroplane with a pressurized cabin:

options.content: is dependent on aerodynamic ceiling
is dependent on the OAT
is only certified for four-engine aeroplanes
is the highest pressure altitude certified for normal operation

questions.question: Why are ˋstep climbsˊ used on long distance flights?

options.content: Step climbs do not have any special purpose for jet aeroplanes; they are used for piston engine aeroplanes only
To respect ATC flight level constraints
To fly as close as possible to the optimum altitude as aeroplane mass reduces
Step climbs are only justified if, at the higher altitude, less headwind or more tailwind can be expected

questions.question: Long range cruise (LRC) instead of best range speed (MRC) is selected because LRC:

options.content: is 4% faster and achieves 99% of maximum specific range in zero wind
is the speed for best range
is the speed for best economy
gives higher specific range with tailwind

questions.question: What happens when an aeroplane climbs at a constant Mach number?

options.content: IAS stays constant so there will be no problems
The “1.3g” altitude is exceeded, so Mach buffet will start immediately
The lift coefficient increase
The TAS continues to increase, which may lead to structural problems

questions.question: The speed range between low speed buffet and high speed buffet:

options.content: decreases with increasing mass and is independent of altitude
is only limiting at low altitudes
increases with increasing mass
narrows with increasing mass and increasing altitude

questions.question: A jet aeroplane descends with constant Mach number. Which of the following speed limits is most likely to be exceeded first?

options.content: Maximum Operational Mach Number
Maximum Operating Speed
Never Exceed Speed
High Speed Buffet Limit

questions.question: With respect to the optimum altitude, which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: An aeroplane always flies below the optimum altitude, because Mach buffet might occur
An aeroplane always flies at the optimum altitude because this is economically seen as the most attractive altitude
An aeroplane flies most of the time above the optimum altitude because this yields the most economic result
An aeroplane sometimes flies above or below the optimum altitude because optimum altitude increases continuously during flight

questions.question: The aerodynamic ceiling:

options.content: is the altitude at which the aeroplane reaches 50 ft/min
is the altitude at which the speeds for low speed buffet and for high speed buffet are the same
depends upon thrust setting and increases with increasing thrust
is the altitude at which the best rate of climb theoretically is zero

questions.question: An aeroplane operating under the 180 minutes ETOPS rule may be up to:

options.content: 180 minutes flying time to a suitable airport in still air with one engine inoperative
180 minutes flying time to a suitable airport under the prevailing weather condition with one engine inoperative
180 minutes flying time from suitable airport in still air at a normal cruising speed
90 minutes flying time from the first en route airport and another 90 minutes from the second en route airport in still air with one engine inoperative

questions.question: If the climb speed schedule is changed from 280/.74 to 290/.74 the new crossover altitude is:

options.content: unchanged
only affected by the aeroplane gross mass
lower
higher

questions.question: The drift down procedure specifies requirements concerning the:

options.content: engine power at the altitude at which engine failure occurs
climb gradient during the descent to the net level-off altitude
weight during landing at the alternate
obstacle clearance during descent to the net level-off altitude

questions.question:
For this question use Figure 4.24 in CAP 698 Section 4.

With regard to the drift down performance of the twin jet aeroplane, why does the curve representing 35 000 kg gross mass in the chart for drift down net profiles start at approximately 3 minutes at FL370?

options.content: Because at this mass the engines slow down at a slower rate after failure, there is still some thrust left during four minutes
Due to higher TAS at this mass it takes more time to develop the optimal rate of descent, because of the inertia involved
All the curves start at the same point, which is situated outside the chart
Because at this mass it takes about 3 minutes to decelerate to the optimum speed for drift down at the original cruising level

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: An engine failure at high cruising altitude will always result in a drift down, because it is not permitted to fly the same altitude as with all engines operating
When determining the obstacle clearance during drift down, fuel dumping may be taken into account
The drift down regulations require a minimum descent angle after an engine failure at cruising altitude
The drift down procedure requires a minimum obstacle clearance of 35 ft

questions.question: The drift down requirements are based on:

options.content: the actual engine thrust output at the altitude of engine failure
the maximum flight path gradient during the descent
the landing mass limit at the alternate
the obstacle clearance during a descent to the new cruising altitude if an engine has failed

questions.question: If the level-off altitude is below the obstacle clearance altitude during a drift down procedure:

options.content: fuel jettisoning should be started at the beginning of drift down
the recommended drift down speed should be disregarded and it should be flown at the stall speed plus 10 kt
fuel jettisoning should be started when the obstacle clearance altitude is reached
the drift down should be flown with flaps in the approach configuration

questions.question: After engine failure the aeroplane is unable to maintain its cruising altitude. What is the procedure which should be applied?

options.content: Emergency descent procedure
ETOPS
Long range cruise des
Drift down procedure

questions.question:
For this question use Figure 4.24 of CAP 698 Section 4.

With regard to the drift down performance of the twin jet aeroplane, what is meant by “equivalent gross weight at engine failure”?

options.content: The increment accounts for the higher fuel flow at higher temperatures
The equivalent gross weight at engine failure is the actual gross weight corrected for OAT higher than ISA +10°C
The increment represents fuel used before engine failure
This gross weight accounts for the lower Mach number at higher temperatures

questions.question: ˋDrift downˊ is the procedure to be applied:

options.content: to conduct a visual approach if VASI is available
after engine failure if the aeroplane is above the one engine out maximum altitude
after cabin depressurization
to conduct an instrument approach at the alternate

questions.question: In a twin-engine jet aircraft with six passenger seats, and a maximum certified take-off mass of 5650 kg, what is the required en route obstacle clearance, with one engine inoperative during drift down towards the alternate airport?

options.content: 50 ft or half the wingspan

questions.question: Below the optimum cruise altitude:

options.content: the IAS for long range cruise increases continuously with decreasing altitude
the Mach number for long range cruise decreases continuously with decreasing altitude
the Mach number for long range cruise decreases continuously with an increasing mass at a constant altitude
the Mach number for long range cruise increases continuously with decreasing mass at a constant altitude

questions.question: How does the long range cruise speed (LRC) change?

options.content: LRC Mach number decreases with decreasing altitude
LRC Mach number decreases with increasing altitude
LRC indicated airspeed increases with increasing altitude
LRC true airspeed decreases with increasing altitude

questions.question: If a flight is performed with a higher “cost index” at a given mass, which of the following will occur?

options.content: A better maximum range
A higher cruise Mach number
A lower cruise Mach number
A better long range

questions.question: The effect of flying at the long range cruise speed instead of the maximum range cruise speed is:

options.content: fuel flow is reduced and speed stability is improved
fuel flow is reduced and speed stability is reduced
fuel flow is increased and speed stability is improved
fuel flow is increased and speed stability is reduced

questions.question: An aircraftˊs descent speed schedule is M 0.74 / 250 KIAS. During the descent from 30 000 ft to sea level, the angle of attack will:

options.content: decrease, then remain constant
increase, then remain constant
remain constant
decrease

questions.question: During a drift down following engine failure, what would be the correct procedure to follow?

options.content: Begin fuel jettison immediately, commensurate with having required reserves at destination
Do not commence fuel jettison until en route obstacles have been cleared
Descend in the approach configuration
Disregard the flight manual and descend at V<sub>S</sub> + 10 kt to the destination
